summary: try and guess how tony feels, not knowing whos still alive, and that those who are he let down for God knows what time, he...
body:
try and guess how tony feels, not knowing whos still alive, and that those who are he let down for God knows what time, he doesnt know if its christmas or not, maybe it passed last week, maybe he’ll pass away, maybe then he wont feel like hes undone every right thing he bled for to make amends for his past, maybe he deserves this but God, they dont, none of them do.

goodbye, pepper, and im sorry i left and that now you have to cancel the interior designer you hired to make the room next to ours into a nursery. goodbye, rhodey, and im sorry for never making up for everything you sacrificed for me. goodbye, peter, and im sorry i couldnt bring you home safe and spare your aunt the heartbreak, kid, had i known what strange had in mind id have traded places with you. im sorry, harley, that i left without saying goodbye. God, im no better than that bastard was, am i? and fuck, yinsen, im sorry you died only for me to fail you. shouldve been the other way round.

summary: wish for winter winds to be kind on harley keener whos sitting on his porch late at night this christmas, staring up at the sky...
body:
wish for winter winds to be kind on harley keener whos sitting on his porch late at night this christmas, staring up at the sky with eyes that refuse to dry and leaving a hundredth voicemail knowing tony wont respond, because he cant respond even if hes still alive, but still some stupid childish part of him believes in christmas miracles and tonys genius enough to wait in freezing cold for headlights that wont come and a present he wont get, ever again.

(oh, and all the messages say the same.)

(“you promised me, tony. that you wouldnt leave.”)

(“why did you leave me too?”)

summary: headcanon: all the kids in the new york foster homes are gonna be really confused when instead of their uncle tony they get this...
body:
headcanon: all the kids in the new york foster homes are gonna be really confused when instead of their uncle tony they get this lovely lady with tears on her face giving them their christmas presents this year. they ask her where tony is and she tells them hes up there among the stars, making sure the world stays safe for the rest of them. the kids, of course, believe her, some cause they dont know better, others cause they desperately want to, and she swallows the tears and the bitter taste of lies cause she lost hope a week ago and pulled out tony’s will that had “give kids at foster homes of new york christmas presents” at the top of the list.

(she made it to the part where he wrote in the inheritence of the child they were supposed to have together and wished she turned to ashes too.)

blog.name: irondad-and-spiderson-stuff
blog.title: Irondad and Spiderson
blog.description: Mainly fics from my book on Wattpad, or random headcanons that pop up

body:
Angst??

Peter gasped, eyes burning as he finally manages to open his eyes. But wait. Where’s Mr. Stark? Feeling around blindly for his dad. No, not his dad. His dad died in a crash. His mentor, Mr. Stark. He can’t breath he can’t breath he can’t breath. Why can’t he breath?What even happened? Why was he on the ground, why was he hurting? Where is Mr. Stark? Oh The fall, the fire, the building. The crushing weight on his back. Oh, that’s why he can’t breath. The building on him, his lungs filled with smoke, his vision blurring with tears he refused to let fall, because he will be saved. Mr. Stark is coming to save him, everything will be okay. But seconds turned to minutes, which turned to hours, or what felt like so. Every passing minute Peter lost his hope piece by piece. Where is Mr. Stark?Why isn’t he coming to save him?

Choking sobs back as he tried to think of anything but the man, but he couldn’t. Why?

Slowly, he lost himself. His mind going blank. He was prepared to leave this world behind if it meant he had done even a spec of good for someone. If he had saved someone..

Because really, he deserved this, right? 

Because if even Mr. Stark wasn’t coming for him, then he must be a monster.

Peter relied on him too much, didn’t he? He tends to do that a lot, huh? Maybe he scared him away. Maybe… Maybe.

With a final rattling breath, Peter stilled. The final tear falling from his open lash, and streaking his cheek. His usually bright eyes now dull and the life sucked out of them.

His body lay motionless among the the rubble of the fallen building. The fire still blazing about, until it engulfed him.

When the firefighters finally got the fire out, they were told to keep a look out for Spiderman. They found him, sure. His body burnt is so many different places, his suit barely recognizable. But his eyes. His eyes were still open, staring lifelessly ahead.

The man who discovered him felt his stomach churn. Who’s kid had been saving the city? Who’s kid have the police been continuously shooting at? Who’s kid is laying dead in the rubble of the fire?

Tony Stark pushed his way through the crowd to get to the scene. His kid, he needs his kid

He pulled the yellow tape back and looked around as he walked in. The firefighter cam out of the smoke and rubble, carrying a limp form. The man carrying him was obviously deeply disturbed.“My kid!” Tony yelled

He raced over to his kid, but when he reached them, he was met with a very angry face.“How could you let him do this? He’s obviously just a kid. His eyes. He was obviously in fear before he died,” The firefighter yelled at him. Tony stopped, blinked a second. His kid, is dead?Peter, his little ball of sunshine, the reason he’s sober, the reason he’s alive… is dead.

Worst of all, he died in fear. 

“Hey Mr. Stark! What’s the news today?”

“No! That’s not fair! You cheater”

“You know, I like you a lot better when you’re sober, Mr. Stark”

“Mr. Stark… I don’t feel so good”

Tony felt his heart hammer in his chest.

my account name is pettifogging and the story it is under is called marvel rant book
summary: @ marvel cinematic universe: step ya pussy up honey
body:
@ marvel cinematic universe: step ya pussy up honey

Comics have been a staple in modern culture because of how long they’ve represented us, the readers. When the main character feels that immense pain of losing a loved one? We feel that. When the main character finally gets their guy/girl/person? We relate to that too, eyeing our significant others. When a character faces an important and difficult challenge and only perseveres through pure will? We get it, most of us go to school! The point I’m trying to make is, comics represent us through their colorful art, excellent writing, and understandable plot lines. The same cannot be said for movie adaptations. When a movie is based of a book, comic, or any other work of literature, some stuff is bound to be cut out. Movies are so desperate to get to the cool action scenes, or the heartfelt romance scenes that they completely skim over what made the readers love that piece of literature in the first place.

Which is why I’m begging the MCU to get their shit together. For years, the MCU has dipped in the Marvel Comics, taken out somewhat interesting plot lines and characters they believe will sell, and thrown the rest out, and I am not a fan. This “pick and discard” method is truly shown through two main topics: ethnicity and the lgbtq+ community (I know there are a ton of topics that the MCU likes to skim over. I’m aware of them, and I don’t like that they’re left behind the curtains. I want to inform y’all of some problems I see in the MCU, and there are so many that I don’t think one chapter will do it service.). So let’s get this shit show started!

Ethnicity:

This is probably the most noticeable problem in the MCU. Everyone in the movies are predominantly Caucasian/European/of European descent. Go watch three marvel movies right now, and count how many people of color you see. I’ll be you my life savings of thirty-seven dollars and ninety-two cents that the number doesn’t exceed ten. That is ridiculous. We, as fans, go to these movies every few years to see people like us do things we could never do in a relatable, PG-13 way. But they aren’t like us. Well, not like colored people, I should say. We don’t see enough of brown or black-skinned characters being bad bitches. We don’t see enough brown or black-skinned characters getting the girl, the guy or the person of their affections. We don’t see enough brown or black-skinned characters succeeding, failing, suffering, thriving or living. And that’s a real problem.

———————————————————

“Uhhhh, actually,” the privileged white fanboys begin, “Colored people do have representation. You guys have War Machine, and uh, and Falcon, and Black Panther! You have Black Panther! And Heimdall.”

“That’s four people,” us poc fans say tiredly. “Four out of how many white characters in the MCU?”

Our question throws them off. “Well uh, you also have Luis from Ant-Man! He’s Hispanic! And, and there’s that one chick from Age of Ultron! She was Asian, right? Right?”

We sigh. “The fact that you can’t even remember Helen’s name proves our point for us. The MCU is not engineered towards people of color.”

The fanboys pale, spluttering. “You pry for representation, but are ungrateful with what you have? Fam and disgusting. Shut up and go whine somewhere else.”

Us poc fans, not even wanting to deal with that mess, sigh once more and sit silently, wishing for change and wondering when things aren’t going to be like this.

———————————————————

That whole exchange I just wrote was scripted, but based off of real events. There are a lot of things I despise about the way colored characters are handled, but here are the final cherries on top:

•The Black Best Friend: A BBF, by my definition, is a black character that only exists to support a white character. Go watch the second Iron Man movie, the second Captain America movie, and the second Thor movie. Rhodey, Sam and Heimdall are all casted into the BBF role. Rhodey is only there to support Tony, Sam is only there to support Steve, and Heimdall is only there to support Thor. Rhodey, Sam and Heimdall barely branch outside of their supporting roles, which sucks because they’re interesting characters with amazing actors. They are the core definition of a BBF, and I hate that because that’s all they are in the MCU. Go watch any movie these three are in and give me a moment that doesn’t revolve around their white counterpart. Seriously, go find one. I want to see if one actually exists. Bonus points if they join the white hero’s cause in the middle/towards the end if the movie (Yes, I’m aware that they all do that. I just wanted to give you all a freebie. Good luck for anyone who actually tries though.).

•Kill/Harm Your Colored Characters: Heimdall, stabbed to death in the first five minutes of Infinity War. Sam Wilson, turned to dust at the end of Infinity War. T’Challa Udaku, thrown off a waterfall whilst bleeding out and turned to dust at the end of Infinity War. Shuri Udaku, turned to dust offscreen in Infinity War. James “Rhodey” Rhodes, had legs replaced with prosthetics after falling from the sky in Captain America:Civil War. Helen Cho, found bleeding to death in her lab in Avengers:Age of Ultron. These are some of the casualties of Marvel not knowing how to handle colored characters. Sure, most of these were/will be fixed, but the point still stands. People will try and argue that white characters have also suffered, and I agree, everyone’s gotten the short stick once or twice, but their suffering should not overtake the suffering of colored characters. The worst part about the list at the start of this paragraph? There are so many more that I haven’t listed that can go on that list.

•Erasing Accomplishments of Colored Characters: Before I start this, let it be said: I love Tony Stark, Bruce Banner, and Stephen Strange. Just because I’m talking about them in this chapter does not mean I do not appreciate their accomplishments as well. Shuri Udaku and Helen Cho are some of the smartest women-and people- in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and Marvel Comics, so why are their accomplishments overshadowed by their white counterparts? Shuri saved a man thousands in medical bills and physical therapy, yet I see no one talking about this like it never happened? I am very well aware of how Shuri has been presented as a meme-loving teen in the MCU but still. She’s not the head of Wakanda’s technological department for nothing. Y’all stay sleeping on Shuri changing countless lives with her tech-including Bucky’s-but all y’all seem to stay awake for is Stephen dying and then telling someone else how to save his life. What? Helen made a machine able to genetically clone tissues to help people heal faster, but the only thing y’all seem to remember from Age of Ultron is how smart Bruce and Tony are for building Ultron, who used Helen’s machine to make clones of themself (something they couldn’t do before). Are you serious? Did we not watch the same movies? Shuri and Helen have both done nothing but advance the S.T.E.M. world with their inventions, but all y’all seem to do is ignore them and their successes in favor of talking about white men. Wow.

•Shipping: Nothing pisses me off more then how shipping is handled in the MCU fandom. Stucky? Cool! Stony? Awesome! Spideypool? Iconic! Samsteve, Iron Husbands, or Interwebs? Uh, they’re friends? Why would you ship them. That’s so gross! Do. You. See. The. Problem. Ships featuring a colored individual and a white person are either deemed nasty demoted to “rare-pair” status because someone that isn’t white is in the ship. Some of y’all will sooner ship incest (Thorki) or pedophilia (Starker) than harmless ships like Thorkyrie or Spideychelle, who both involve colored characters. And this isn’t just for ships with two people. This goes for ships with three people as well. Y’all have no problem shipping Stuckony, or Dr. Pepperony, but the second someone says: “Oh, I like Samstevebucky or Pepper x Tony x Rhodey,” people start to ignore the ship or say: “That’s too many people!” Just say you’re racist and move along.

LGBTQ+ Community:

There is no greater feeling than seeing yourself in modern media in a way that is fulfilling and not offensively. This is especially the case for those of us who are apart of the lgbtq+ community. If we’re not being told we’re “wrong” or “sinful” for liking who we like or identifying as who we identify, we’re being slandered and harrassed. Which is why seeing super-powered individuals that are just like us being handled well by writers and not rendered to useless side-characters is so good. No, it’s better than good. It’s marvelous. Everytime I see Lady Loki, America Chavez, Bobby Drake, Karolina Dean, Teddy Altman, Billy Kaplan, or any of the numerous lgbtq+ characters in Marvel Comics, I smile, because Marvel Comics gets it. They understand our need for representation, and I am forever grateful for their strive to include us. That being said, the Marvel Cinematic Universe needs to step up. There are over two hundred canonically lgbtq+ that are in the marvel canon, and only a few of them have made it on the MCU’s character roster. And that’s not saying much, considering not a one of these characters were shown/coded to be gay, lesbian, bi, trans, genderfluid, nonbinary, et cera. Which makes one start to wonder: why? Why go through the trouble of making so many lgbtq+ characters if the MCU is adamant on making sure they aren’t shown on screen? To which I can only answer: Marvel Studios wants money. When you have a franchise as successful as Marvel, you start to shift your focus on the cash and the fans that gave you that cash. You start to find patterns. Oh, these fans liked these over-dramatic fight scenes? Let’s dedicate two-thirds of our movie to that and forget about concise plot! Oh, these fans like this female actress because she’s hot and has a subpar romance with our main man? Let’s give her some more roles and not expand her character! Oh, the straight cis fans like this straight cis character? Let’s deny their identity because this is what the fans want! No, it’s what you’ve heard from the most vocal opinions of characters.

White, straight, cis and Christian parents watch these movies with their kids, and lemme tell you, if a character even looked at a character of the same gender for more than a reasonable time there’d be an uproar. And Marvel Studios doesn’t want an uproar (unless it’s positive, of course). They want money. So they’re perfectly fine with expunging the identities of millions for the sake of that coin. And it’s ridiculous. And that’s not to say that everyone at Marvel Studios is selfish. I’m sure some people there get it, and want to do more. Stan did, bless his soul. But there needs to be a greater effort. Making movies built towards underrepresented crowds is always a guarantee for success. Don’t believe me? Go watch Love, Simon, or Black Panther, or any movie that has made bank and a universal impact on those it was trying to portray. This is why people cling to the fandom side of the MCU, where people will understand your pain of not seeing your lgbtq+ fave on screen and recommend fanfiction or fanart of that character that the MCU chooses to believe does not exist. Maybe one day Marvel Studios will get it. Maybe one day, we’ll be able to walk out of a movie theater, beaming, because two boys kissed on screen. But until then, I’m not holding my breath. I’m reading the comics.

To make a long story short, the MCU doesn’t know what diversity and representation are and are thus incapable of depicting them on screen. My advice? Read the comics, they are infintely better.

@ marvel cinematic universe: step ya pussy up honey

Comics have been a staple in modern culture because of how long they’ve represented us, the readers. When the main character feels that immense pain of losing a loved one? We feel that. When the main character finally gets their guy/girl/person? We relate to that too, eyeing our significant others. When a character faces an important and difficult challenge and only perseveres through pure will? We get it, most of us go to school! The point I’m trying to make is, comics represent us through their colorful art, excellent writing, and understandable plot lines. The same cannot be said for movie adaptations. When a movie is based of a book, comic, or any other work of literature, some stuff is bound to be cut out. Movies are so desperate to get to the cool action scenes, or the heartfelt romance scenes that they completely skim over what made the readers love that piece of literature in the first place.

Which is why I’m begging the MCU to get their shit together. For years, the MCU has dipped in the Marvel Comics, taken out somewhat interesting plot lines and characters they believe will sell, and thrown the rest out, and I am not a fan. This “pick and discard” method is truly shown through two main topics: ethnicity and the lgbtq+ community (I know there are a ton of topics that the MCU likes to skim over. I’m aware of them, and I don’t like that they’re left behind the curtains. I want to inform y’all of some problems I see in the MCU, and there are so many that I don’t think one chapter will do it service.). So let’s get this shit show started!

Ethnicity:

This is probably the most noticeable problem in the MCU. Everyone in the movies are predominantly Caucasian/European/of European descent. Go watch three marvel movies right now, and count how many people of color you see. I’ll be you my life savings of thirty-seven dollars and ninety-two cents that the number doesn’t exceed ten. That is ridiculous. We, as fans, go to these movies every few years to see people like us do things we could never do in a relatable, PG-13 way. But they aren’t like us. Well, not like colored people, I should say. We don’t see enough of brown or black-skinned characters being bad bitches. We don’t see enough brown or black-skinned characters getting the girl, the guy or the person of their affections. We don’t see enough brown or black-skinned characters succeeding, failing, suffering, thriving or living. And that’s a real problem.

———————————————————

“Uhhhh, actually,” the privileged white fanboys begin, “Colored people do have representation. You guys have War Machine, and uh, and Falcon, and Black Panther! You have Black Panther! And Heimdall.”

“That’s four people,” us poc fans say tiredly. “Four out of how many white characters in the MCU?”

Our question throws them off. “Well uh, you also have Luis from Ant-Man! He’s Hispanic! And, and there’s that one chick from Age of Ultron! She was Asian, right? Right?”

We sigh. “The fact that you can’t even remember Helen’s name proves our point for us. The MCU is not engineered towards people of color.”

The fanboys pale, spluttering. “You pry for representation, but are ungrateful with what you have? Fam and disgusting. Shut up and go whine somewhere else.”

Us poc fans, not even wanting to deal with that mess, sigh once more and sit silently, wishing for change and wondering when things aren’t going to be like this.

———————————————————

Rhodey is only there to support Tony, Sam is only there to support Steve, and Heimdall is only there to support Thor. Rhodey, Sam and Heimdall barely branch outside of their supporting roles, which sucks because they’re interesting characters with amazing actors. They are the core definition of a BBF, and I hate that because that’s all they are in the MCU. Go watch any movie these three are in and give me a moment that doesn’t revolve around their white counterpart. Seriously, go find one. I want to see if one actually exists. Go watch three marvel movies right now, and count how many people of color you see. I’ll be you my life savings of thirty-seven dollars and ninety-two cents that the number doesn’t exceed ten. That is ridiculous. We, as fans, go to these movies every few years to see people like us do things we could never do in a relatable, PG-13 way. But they aren’t like us. Well, not like colored people, I should say. We don’t see enough of brown or black-skinned characters being bad bitches. We don’t see enough brown or black-skinned characters getting the girl, the guy or the person of their affections. We don’t see enough brown or black-skinned characters succeeding, failing, suffering, thriving or living. And that’s a real problem.

———————————————————

“Uhhhh, actually,” the privileged white fanboys begin, “Colored people do have representation. You guys have War Machine, and uh, and Falcon, and Black Panther! You have Black Panther! And Heimdall.”

“That’s four people,” us poc fans say tiredly. “Four out of how many white characters in the MCU?”

Our question throws them off. “Well uh, you also have Luis from Ant-Man! He’s Hispanic! And, and there’s that one chick from Age of Ultron! She was Asian, right? Right?”

We sigh. “The fact that you can’t even remember Helen’s name proves our point for us. The MCU is not engineered towards people of color.”

The fanboys pale, spluttering. “You pry for representation, but are ungrateful with what you have? Fam and disgusting. Shut up and go whine somewhere else.”

Us poc fans, not even wanting to deal with that mess, sigh once more and sit silently, wishing for change and wondering when things aren’t going to be like this.

———————————————————

That whole exchange I just wrote was scripted, but based off of real events. There are a lot of things I despise about the way colored characters are handled, but here are the final cherries on top:

•The Black Best Friend: A BBF, by my definition, is a black character that only exists to support a white character. Go watch the second Iron Man movie, the second Captain America movie, and the second Thor movie. Rhodey, Sam and Heimdall are all casted into the BBF role. Rhodey is only there to support Tony, Sam is only there to support Steve, and Heimdall is only there to support Thor. Rhodey, Sam and Heimdall barely branch outside of their supporting roles, which sucks because they’re interesting characters with amazing actors. They are the core definition of a BBF, and I hate that because that’s all they are in the MCU. Go watch any movie these three are in and give me a moment that doesn’t revolve around their white counterpart. Seriously, go find one. I want to see if one actually exists. Bonus points if they join the white hero’s cause in the middle/towards the end if the movie (Yes, I’m aware that they all do that. I just wanted to give you all a freebie. Good luck for anyone who actually tries though.).

•Kill/Harm Your Colored Characters: Heimdall, stabbed to death in the first five minutes of Infinity War. Sam Wilson, turned to dust at the end of Infinity War. T’Challa Udaku, thrown off a waterfall whilst bleeding out and turned to dust at the end of Infinity War. Shuri Udaku, turned to dust offscreen in Infinity War. James “Rhodey” Rhodes, had legs replaced with prosthetics after falling from the sky in Captain America:Civil War. Helen Cho, found bleeding to death in her lab in Avengers:Age of Ultron. These are some of the casualties of Marvel not knowing how to handle colored characters. Sure, most of these were/will be fixed, but the point still stands. People will try and argue that white characters have also suffered, and I agree, everyone’s gotten the short stick once or twice, but their suffering should not overtake the suffering of colored characters. The worst part about the list at the start of this paragraph? There are so many more that I haven’t listed that can go on that list.

•Erasing Accomplishments of Colored Characters: Before I start this, let it be said: I love Tony Stark, Bruce Banner, and Stephen Strange. Just because I’m talking about them in this chapter does not mean I do not appreciate their accomplishments as well. Shuri Udaku and Helen Cho are some of the smartest women-and people- in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and Marvel Comics, so why are their accomplishments overshadowed by their white counterparts? Shuri saved a man thousands in medical bills and physical therapy, yet I see no one talking about this like it never happened? I am very well aware of how Shuri has been presented as a meme-loving teen in the MCU but still. She’s not the head of Wakanda’s technological department for nothing. Y’all stay sleeping on Shuri changing countless lives with her tech-including Bucky’s-but all y’all seem to stay awake for is Stephen dying and then telling someone else how to save his life. What? Helen made a machine able to genetically clone tissues to help people heal faster, but the only thing y’all seem to remember from Age of Ultron is how smart Bruce and Tony are for building Ultron, who used Helen’s machine to make clones of themself (something they couldn’t do before). Are you serious? Did we not watch the same movies? Shuri and Helen have both done nothing but advance the S.T.E.M. world with their inventions, but all y’all seem to do is ignore them and their successes in favor of talking about white men. Wow.

•Shipping: Nothing pisses me off more then how shipping is handled in the MCU fandom. Stucky? Cool! Stony? Awesome! Spideypool? Iconic! Samsteve, Iron Husbands, or Interwebs? Uh, they’re friends? Why would you ship them. That’s so gross! Do. You. See. The. Problem. Ships featuring a colored individual and a white person are either deemed nasty demoted to “rare-pair” status because someone that isn’t white is in the ship. Some of y’all will sooner ship incest (Thorki) or pedophilia (Starker) than harmless ships like Thorkyrie or Spideychelle, who both involve colored characters. And this isn’t just for ships with two people. This goes for ships with three people as well. Y’all have no problem shipping Stuckony, or Dr. Pepperony, but the second someone says: “Oh, I like Samstevebucky or Pepper x Tony x Rhodey,” people start to ignore the ship or say: “That’s too many people!” Just say you’re racist and move along.

LGBTQ+ Community:

There is no greater feeling than seeing yourself in modern media in a way that is fulfilling and not offensively. This is especially the case for those of us who are apart of the lgbtq+ community. If we’re not being told we’re “wrong” or “sinful” for liking who we like or identifying as who we identify, we’re being slandered and harrassed. Which is why seeing super-powered individuals that are just like us being handled well by writers and not rendered to useless side-characters is so good. No, it’s better than good. It’s marvelous. Everytime I see Lady Loki, America Chavez, Bobby Drake, Karolina Dean, Teddy Altman, Billy Kaplan, or any of the numerous lgbtq+ characters in Marvel Comics, I smile, because Marvel Comics gets it. They understand our need for representation, and I am forever grateful for their strive to include us. That being said, the Marvel Cinematic Universe needs to step up. There are over two hundred canonically lgbtq+ that are in the marvel canon, and only a few of them have made it on the MCU’s character roster. And that’s not saying much, considering not a one of these characters were shown/coded to be gay, lesbian, bi, trans, genderfluid, nonbinary, et cera. Which makes one start to wonder: why? Why go through the trouble of making so many lgbtq+ characters if the MCU is adamant on making sure they aren’t shown on screen? To which I can only answer: Marvel Studios wants money. When you have a franchise as successful as Marvel, you start to shift your focus on the cash and the fans that gave you that cash. You start to find patterns. Oh, these fans liked these over-dramatic fight scenes? Let’s dedicate two-thirds of our movie to that and forget about concise plot! Oh, these fans like this female actress because she’s hot and has a subpar romance with our main man? Let’s give her some more roles and not expand her character! Oh, the straight cis fans like this straight cis character? Let’s deny their identity because this is what the fans want! No, it’s what you’ve heard from the most vocal opinions of characters.

White, straight, cis and Christian parents watch these movies with their kids, and lemme tell you, if a character even looked at a character of the same gender for more than a reasonable time there’d be an uproar. And Marvel Studios doesn’t want an uproar (unless it’s positive, of course). They want money. So they’re perfectly fine with expunging the identities of millions for the sake of that coin. And it’s ridiculous. And that’s not to say that everyone at Marvel Studios is selfish. I’m sure some people there get it, and want to do more. Stan did, bless his soul. But there needs to be a greater effort. Making movies built towards underrepresented crowds is always a guarantee for success. Don’t believe me? Go watch Love, Simon, or Black Panther, or any movie that has made bank and a universal impact on those it was trying to portray. This is why people cling to the fandom side of the MCU, where people will understand your pain of not seeing your lgbtq+ fave on screen and recommend fanfiction or fanart of that character that the MCU chooses to believe does not exist. Maybe one day Marvel Studios will get it. Maybe one day, we’ll be able to walk out of a movie theater, beaming, because two boys kissed on screen. But until then, I’m not holding my breath. I’m reading the comics.

To make a long story short, the MCU doesn’t know what diversity and representation are and are thus incapable of depicting them on screen. My advice? Read the comics, they are infintely better.

summary: Oh Christmas Lights, Keep Shining On
title: Oh Christmas Lights, Keep Shining On
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2Rl00NE

by ciaconnaa

Tony isn’t one to hash out the differences between a house and a home. Those kinds of cheesy sayings are better left to soccer moms and Hallmark cards. But standing in the middle of Peter’s kitchen with his sleeves all sudsy, surrounded by pictures, evidence, and history of a house well lived in, Tony can easily define that this is not a house, it’s a home. Peter’s home.

There’s no way he can take Peter away from his home for Christmas. Not when he doesn’t have his aunt anymore.

He makes a decision. A split decision, really. All the details explode in his head like a supernova, like they always do, but it’s a plan. And he’s gonna stick to it.

or;

Tony, Peter, and what it means to be a family.

blog.title: We All Got Crowns
blog.description:
Jo ⎊ she/her ⎊ bi ⎊ 18

Ao3 is Zanareds

Dc and Marvel

tags: I love Sharon and Tony having a sibling relationship
And I am emotional in this chillies tonight
summary: Maria Stark inviting Peggy and Sharon over to celebrate Christmas with her and Tony.... Howard is away of course, he’s never...
body:
Maria Stark inviting Peggy and Sharon over to celebrate Christmas with her and Tony….

Howard is away of course, he’s never home during holidays or birthdays.

Maria can’t stand the face of disappointment every time she had to tell him “Your father has very important things to tend to. He can’t be here.”

So Maria decides to invite the person that Tony adores most in the world (apart from herself and Jarvis)

Peggy was happy to fly in for a visit once she heard her godson needed some cheer.

Sharon insisted on coming as well, wanting to give Tony the present she’d got him in person.

Peg and Sharon arrive with cookies they had made together, surprising Tony on Christmas Eve. He’s ecstatic, clinging to Peggy as he hugs her.

Sharon ruffles his hair and laughs as he swats her hand away, she scrunches her nose and hugs him.

Maria and Peggy catch up as the kids devour the cookies. Tony and Sharon not caring about the icing all over their faces and clothes.

After that, Sharon suggested watching a Christmas movie, she and Tony always ended up using the theater room when she visited. Sharon wanted to watch “It’s a wonderful life” Wich Peggy immediately vetoed.

Tony brought out the “Muppets Christmas Carol”. The four of them popped popcorn, made hot cocoa, and snuggled under blankets as they watched the movie.

Jarvis and Peggy carry the kids to their beds when they fall asleep. Howard is the furthest thing from Tony’s mind. 

Maria could cry at how how happy Tony had been. 

Morning comes, and Sharon wakes first, sneaking past the room Peggy was sleeping in with the stealth of a ninja, Sharon opens the door to Tony’s room.

“Tony! Wake up! It’s Christmas!”

The boy stirs, his eyes still shut looking annoyed at the disturbance.

“C’mon dummy, I want you to open the present I got you before the adults wake up and start taking a bunch of pictures for albums and junk!”

Tony sighs, his eyes open slightly, and Sharon shakes him.

“Stoop…”

“Tony, It’s Christmas. Get your ass up!” 

He cracks a smile, and finally sits up, “Aunt Peggy wouldn’t like that language.”

She rolls her eyes, and practically pulls him out of his bed. They sneak into the living room, where the christmas tree was, and underneath it was a stack of presents. 

“Here!” Sharon excitedly hands Tony the gift she’d wrapped herself.

Tony tears at the paper, and opens the small box. It’s a snowglobe, with a picture of Sharon and Tony in it. The one Aunt Peggy took of them before they got on a roller coaster at Disneyland. 

It was maybe the most precious gift he’d ever been given. So much better than any expensive watch, or any other meaningless item that Howard bought him. 

He hugged her.

The grownups woke up and Tony didn’t think of his father at all as he and his family spent the day unwrapping gifts, playing christmas music, laughing, smiling, dancing. 

They helped Jarvis prepare a big christmas dinner, and ate together at the table, like normal people. like a normal family.

It was the best Christmas Tony had ever had. One he’d remember forever.

Eventually, Peggy and Sharon had to leave. Howard returned a week later with a brief apology. He’d forgotten to get Tony a Christmas present with all the more important work related things around him.

Tony couldn’t bring himself to care. The present wouldn’t have meant anything anyway. He wouldn’t feel  the warmth that he felt everytime he looked at the Snowglobe Sharon gave him, or the pretty journal that had been a present from Peggy.  Not like the little red and gold pendant from Jarvis, or the new sweater from his mom. 

He didn’t care. He didn’t need the formality gifts. He didn’t want them. 

Now, everytime Howard’s coldness gnawed at Tony’s heart, he shook the Snowglobe Sharon had given him, and he was warm again.
